column2: Kitty, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Been taking medication PTU for a week tomorrow morning, so not sure if it is working yet. I take 3 pills a day. I have agreed...yes a bitter lingering taste after taking meds. I have been experiencing some headaches.. Thinking I have to eat with the PTU.. If not the headaches get worse. I will continue meds... Until I do blood test in 3 weeks to see if it's helping the TSH. Is there any recommendations .. I will keep updating as I take meds.

column2: dardykay, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: About 3 months after starting this medication, I had  bllodwork done by my family dr  for  my epilepsy, and he discovered my blood  was "out of whack".  He referred me to the blood  and cancer center, where after 18 tubes of blood  and 2 visits, it was discovered that the propylthiouracil was destroying my blood cells.  During this time, I  also developed a  blistery rash on my hands,  and my regular family dr  referred me to a deratologist, who performed a biopsy, and told me it was because of the thyroid med i was on.  Also, the skin on bottom of both my feet started peeling off...I could actually peel off 3 layers of skin at a time.  I went to my podiatrist (no referral here, i went on my own)  and   was asked  what meds i had been taking, and when i told him propylthiouracil, his exact words were "OH my God"  That is causing  your skin to peel off.  Also, I read  the article where the prescribing dr is to monitor the patient for  any problems...when i told him about the rash, he just said it will go away.  He NEVER did  any bloodwork or anything...good thing my family dr  does  the bloodwork every 6 months for my phenobarbital level because of my epilepsy.  My family dr, when he   heard from the blood and cancer center, called me and said..STOP taking that thyroid medicine.   He wrote  an order for the thyroid dr to perform  a thyroid procedure, but when i  gave  the order to the thyroid dr, on my next visit, he  said Nope...not gonna do that.  Quack  did not monitor me, or  do anything but take my money.

column2: Molly's Mom, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Here's my story: I just gave birth to my 1st baby in December 2010. My doctor suggested I go and see an endocrinologist doctor. After my 3rd(6months from February 2011) visit they finally took my blood and saw that something might be up. The reason for the long wait was because I was/am still nursing. They finally gave me the PTU prescription. I am a little nervous to take because I am still nursing my 7 1/2 month old baby. Anyone else taking this medication and nursing? Or did you have to stop because of the side affects? I would love some feedback on this. Thanks!

column2: karen, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I have been on the medication for approximately 6mos. or more. It seemed to help me feel better, do not like the bitter taste, get it down as quickly as possible. I take 50mg QD, and am under the care of an Endocrinologist. I was on Synthroid for years for underactive thyroid, but has large nodules that are causing overactive so have been placed on this medication to straighten the levels out. Hope I do not have to remain on this medication indefinetely,but the only other option is removal of my thryroid gland.

column2: Skittler, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I was diagnosed with severe hyperthyroidism with swollen glands. My heart rate was constantly 140-150bpm and now Im looking at 78-88bpm. THRILLED. I am taking the maximum dose 1,200mg a day (6 -50mg tablets 4x a day) It is hard for me to remember to take it four times a day. But Hyperthyroid comes with memory problems sometimes. :) The medication is slowly working. I keep getting blood drawn and it's still not down enough... Next option is surgery, so I am really hoping this maximum dose (went from 900- 1200mg) will knock it down a couple more steps.

column2: gina.zeolla@gmail.com, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: before i was diagnosed, i was feeling sick.  my great dr. put me on the (plu) Dr. talk for propylylthiouracil, in 2 weeks i felt like a million bucks.

column2: mazie, 65-74 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Low thyroid

column2: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I have been n remission from hyperthyroidism for the past 2 years due to this medication.  I did not have to have my thyroid removed or kill it by taken medicine.  I highly recommend this drug for Hyperthyoidism (Graves Disease).

column2: snefru,  Male  (Patient)
column9: Was diagnosed 5 years ago with Graves, was losing weight, night sweats, loss of sleep, tremors and terrible aching legs. Dr. put me on PTU, and within 6 weeks I noticed marked improvements in my symptoms. The PTU has  given me few side-effects after 5 years, but food is just not very interesting to me anymore. I just eat because everyone else does, or it is the appropriate time to eat, never eating alot at any one time. I have hit a plateau on my weight though, and it is well short (15-18#) of my normal, healthy weight. I still have some slight tremors in my index fingers from time to time, but nothing like the full-on tremors I was having at the onset of the Graves. I still have episodes of complete exhaustion after about 5 hours of work, but at least I can work now. The major problem I have now is intolerance to heat. Being in the direct sunlight, when it's hot, like 90-95F, is extremely hard to do, and I avoid it at all cost. I don't know if it's a symptom of the Graves, or a side-effect from the PTU. I suspect it's the Graves. I do have mild joint pain from time to time, but I suspect that's the Graves too. I will continue to take the PTU as long as the blood tests show no liver problems. This drug has been moderately effective for me. I'm certainly better than I was.

column1: Symptoms arising in Severe Thyrotoxicosis Thyroid Crisis

column9: bad rashes all over body, nausa, extreme tiredness.  I feel worse now then I did before the medication.

column2: ybarrett, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Yes they are horrible tasting. I was put on them in prep of surgery. Since taking them my pulse is normal (88) when at the beginning it was 100. I feel more calm, my heart is no longer pounding.

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)

Symptoms still present with 800mg/d and other problems are starting to arise or get worse since starting this med - such as very large, baseball sized hives on my lower body - difficulty sleeping / staying asleep - extreme fatigue - So far, I'm not impressed with this drug whatsoever.

column2: simone, 35-44 Female  (Patient)
column9: My doctor tells me this medication is working but I am not sure. Before being dignoised with hyperthyroism I didn't even know anything I was wrong. I was tired and sometimes very itchy but I fell like I still have those problems and even worse I am hot all the time for now reason. I find hard to remember to take 8 pills a day unless I take them all at once. They taste horrible and I feel as if my appetite has increase since taking this medicine. Somedays I feel like I can deal with all the other side effects if I could just get rid of the headach. I have noticed when I take them everything is bright for about 30 min seems strange but my doc says he has never heard that complaint. Just wondering if anyone else has had this problem.

column2: christopher, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Its takes forever for me to get the taste out of my mouth but it does seen to be helping,its been a very slow process ..And i have to take 6 50mg pills every 6 hours ,so i was`nt kidding when i said i have to deal with the taste ..

column2: brenda, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: i am on this pill 4 pills twice a day  is this to much eyes are so muh worse since starting this med.

column2: Faifai66@aol.com, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I have put on weight and it's hard to control.

column2: luvsjags, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I just started taking this med and the bitterness is horrible.  I kept gagging and vomiting.  I melted chocolate chips, dipped the pills in them and put them in the fridge.  They go down perfectly and the bitterness is gone, still get a bit of the bitter taste in my mouth but nothing like before.  My Dr thought it was a great idea, said the chocolate would melt right away and the pill would still be effective.

column2: Fletcher44, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: The PTU is working for Graves symptoms but I am having swollen eye lids and now swelling in my knees and ankles and weight gain. I was on 3 pills 3 times a day and becoming hypo. It was reduced to 2 pills 3 times a day. I think the swelling is from still too much medication. Just called Dr. again.

column2: Cindy, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I've been on PTU off and on for 5 years, developed postpartum Graves disease, was in remission for a while and got it again after my second child. It takes a while to kick in, but overall it worked for me and I am hoping to go in remission again. Lately have a bit of upset stomach and am petrified of liver failure but Methimazole didn't work for me and other alternatives such as radioactive ablation or surgery just seem too drastic. Currently I am better but TSH is still low so my doc wants me to continue on PTU 200 mg a day, I would love to lower my dosage. It takes time...Hope this review helps.

column2: boomobile, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: When I was 14 I was the 9th person ever to be diagnosed with drug-induced hepatitis within the US.For those of you who refuse to take this drug - I understand I am one of the 1 in 100 to have a severe allergic reaction to it - my liver shut down, and I got a nasty rash. I was hospitalized and got off the drug, but this presented another problem. No way to treat my hyperthyroidism. Long story short, my thyroid was removed completely, and now I take T4 replacement hormone for the rest of my life. It's much better than migraines, vomiting, shakiness, pounding heart, weight loss (unhealthy), super sensitive reflexes, and over all jitters.

column2: 13-18 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: the medicine does not affect any part of my mentally nor physical.

column2: vickie, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: i took this for three days. was very sick with it, the worst sore throat ever, all over sick. dr said was not from the med to keep taking it. i did not! within 24 hrs i was well. have not been back since. would like to find something to help me.

column2: Will, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Ok heres my story, I've know since 16yoa I have had graves disease/ Hyperthyroid. I had no way to treat my condition for some time. I visited a Dr at 23yoa who related that I in fact had a hyperthyroid. At first the Dr prescribed propanolol, which made me feel aweful, so I stopped taking the medication. For years I've dealt with pounding heart beat, heart beat skipping, shaking hands, the appearance of nervousness, headaches I would ignore. Additionally I had more energy than anyone around me, but this is not a good feature. As of this date, Feb 2010, I recently experienced what I can only assume was a heart flutter in my upper atrial portion of my heart. It felt as if I had a hamster in my chest. I decided to lie down, and even at rest the fluttering continued. (15) minutes later, with still no relief, I drove to a 24 medical center where they immediately nearly slammed me on a bed and was injecting me with medication, and crap. the fluttering stopped after a short time, and the staff transported me to a telemetry heart floor. (Note: I was the youngest person on this floor of the hospital, what an uneasy feeling). According to the cardiologist, the flutter may have been the result of not taking care of my thyroid issue. (Suggestion to all who read this), take the thyroid med no matter how it makes you feel, and discuss with your Dr any systom or side effects you experience. The biggest pain in Forida is finding an endocrinologist who will actually see you for more than one visit. Back on topic, I am takig this medication identified as Propylthiouracil (50)mg tablets. I have been taking the meds 2xday/ x1 every 6 hours. The actual dosage x2 3xday. This sounds like a lot to me, and I don't want to have liver damage down the road. I have noticed improvement. Hand shaking is minimal and no pounding heart be as yet. Duration of medication consumption x1 mth. Support always appreciated, ty for reading. Will (w_leffew@hotmail.com).

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I have periodically been on and off this drug since 2002.  My Grave's Disease is completely controlled by it and I gradually go off the meds as Grave's goes into remission.  The only effect I have from this drug is that it works COMPLETELY, and effectively!  To deal with the taste I put it way in the back of my throat and must be sure to swallow it with the first gulp of water - then there is NO bad after taste.  If that is the only problem that you have with the drug, then be very happy that a drug can completely elimiate all of the bad parts of Grave's with such a trivial side effect!

column2: Confused, 25-34 on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I really do not know what to think of this drug at all.

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: Have been taking this for 8 or 9 years now.  It has controlled my hyperthyroidism completely.  No more unexplained weight loss (darn it!), rapid heartbeat, trembling hands and horrible diarrhea.  I take 5 pills a day, (2 in morning, 3 at night).  Never noticed any bitter aftertaste, but now that I think about it, I do chew more gum now than I used to...  Also, just today I read something about there being an FDA warning about liver damage as a result of using PTU.  I definitely need to check into this.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Was diagnosed with hyperthyroidism in pregnancy and the Dr. prescribed PTU. My dose was pretty high, 2 pills x  3 times a day, but within 2 months, I suffered acute liver failure as a result of the PTU. Had a liver transplant in August 2009 and thyroidectomy thereafter...

All my levels are normal, incl TSH.  Now Im on 50 mg/d.  Since Id been taking this pill, I hv no adverse rcn. fr. it, so far.

column2: allie, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: It seems to be helping with the symptoms of my over active thyroid.  I've been on it two weeks (1 pill 3x a day) but am having extreme hives and itching.  Mainly on my hands and feet.  my doctor only wants me on this drug for 1 year due to possible liver problems.  having to skip a pill tonight due to the hives.

column2: Brooke, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: My experience has been that it is quite difficult to get the correct dosage.  It tastes awful!

column2: Britney, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I have only been taking PTU a short time but, so far it has worked.  Although, I am still suffering some of the symptoms they have decreased substantially.  The pills do leave a bitter taste in your mouth but, only if they touch your tongue.  For this I recommend covering the pill completely in a spoonful of applesauce or yogurt and then swallowing as soon as it hits your mouth.  By doing so I am no longer experiencing the bitterness at all.

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I have been on this medication for the last week. For months i have been experiencing irritablity, depression, my nervous are shot 24/7, i use to weigh about 98-100lbs and i dropped 10 in one week, i get hot flashes behind my neck and all over my joint areas, i have been having outrageous mood swing almost lost my friends over this crap, i feel out of control and nervous my heart is always racing and i tremble all the time, my hair falls out in large amounts im only 22 and dealing with this crap all ready and i have felt so out of control never use to be that way i tried to take methmazole or w/e it is that put me in the hospital after to weeks, i went to an endo who said i dont have a hyperthyroid...my bw and thyroid scan disagree he shunned me off and gave me crazy pills..i now see a dr at a gyn who has given me ptu...no shakes...no nerves going nuts, less hair falling out..besides sore muscles which i can handle and medium nausea and headaches..so far so good it takes time but its doing the job so far...we shall see the improvement if any more in a few months! fingers are crossed! gl to anyone else

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Just started on this drug to treat hyperactive thyroid. Don't find that there is a problem with a bad taste yet. I had tachycardia and hot flashes and sore joints before taking this drug. Since being on the drug I haven't had the tachycardia and sore joints. However, I have had problems with a scratchy irritation in my throat, which causes me to cough more. Drinking fluids or using lozenges does not help much. Hoping that with a few more months of treatment I will see this symptom go away also. I also noticed that I am tired more and seem to require more sleep than before.

column2: sms_jan, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I have been through HELL. I have aortic stenosis, my Dr. prescribed this med, my heart nearly flew out of my chest. He kept upping my blood pressure meds.  The only way that I found out that this med was NOT to be taken by heart patients was through this website. Honestly, I am sure that I was dying, I was well on my way to a major heart attack. The surgeon that was to take out the thyroid said "No Way", "the shape that your heart is in now, I can not put you to sleep."  I know the awful taste that was spoken about on this site, it was terrible, it kept comming back. I was also very jittery and restless, anxious. This may sound gross, for that I do apologize, but my urine made me ill, the smell was sickening.  I quit the med cold turkey when I read the info.  I will report it to FDA site, I will also call the number listed, as the paper that I received when I first got this medication filled said NOTHING, NOTHING at all about killing you if you have heart trouble. Beware if you are taking this medication, make sure that your heart does not have any, ANY type of problem, including a murmur, no matter how slight. Honestly, I cannot caution you enough; this medication has really hurt me.

column2: bbailen, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I was diagnosed with graves disease two weeks ago. I seen a specialist he recommended these pills 4 50 mg pills 3 times a day so thats 12 pills then I take propranolol 2 pills 4 times a day before this I didnt even take tylenol I take a total of 20 pills a day... I should feel better but I dont I feel worst and now I am emotionally disturbed thinking I take more pills than a dying person with cancer...My body hurts I feel sick 80% of the time cause the other 20% I am trying to sleep so far the sleeping aint been to bad mostly cause my body is drained and I cant help but sleep like a coma patient! I feel feverish most of the time so welcome chills! I had but two addictions and now I say good bye to nicotine and caffeine...I guess that makes me healthier NOT!I am sicker than when I first went to the doctor but no worries the doctor has me takin this med for two more weeks then it is the next step iodine or removal!

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: It will be 4 years since I first started taking PTU.  The drug has worked very well for me.  I take a very low dose now 1 50mg pill a day, this was after the first three months of twice a day 4 50 mg pills.  The taste was awfully bitter; then I did lose the ability to taste most bitter things.  I do not wish to still be on any med.  Waiting to have a more permanent solution like surgery or radiological drug.  Due to an additional issue with an over-active Parathyroid gland that has not shown up in scans to pinpoint surgery; still waiting to treat both with surgery at the same time.

column2: Moe, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I started out on Tapazole and I was sick everyday, allday.  I had to stop the meds when I went on vacation. My Dr changed it to PTU and I feel 100% better.  No side effects. I can deal with the bitter taste for 5 min afterwards.

column2: Taylor1564, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I have had a full day's experience with the med so far.  Last night I had a slight headache and my left knee was sore, but since then I've had no side effects.  I noticed that after I walked up and down the stairs today I could actually breathe! I was diagnosed with Grave's Disease yesterday and my doctor put me on 100mg three time/day of the Propylthiouracil.  So far I'm impressed.

column2: Taylor1564, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I have not started taking my medication yet, I will start it in a few hours to make sure I can keep an 8 hour schedule. I'm very nervous that I may experience joint/muscle pain- of all the side effects that seems the worst to me.  I have had an undiagnosed hyperactive thyroid for over 4 years, so I have experiences severe upset stomachs, extreme shortness of breath and a heart rate of over 200. With the horrible symptoms I've already had I'm hoping the side effects of the medication will be worth it.

column2: bonnie, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: my arm and legs hurt so bad I can barely walk, or lift anything. I am so tired, and I feel like shit. I am going off this medicine and will deal with heart palpations.I felt better before I took this medicine. I never had joint pain. now I do. My heart was acting up, and I am allergic to iodine! I am going to find a new doctor right away, someone needs to find out why so many women have thyroid problems. I was better off the medicine.

column2: MonaLisa, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I had very little problem with this drug.My Dr increases or decreased as needed. She tripled my dosage then, I ran a temperature every night with fever and chills. I began to have bruising on my ear lobes and face, lupus like symptoms. I could not go outside for more than 15 mins because my heart fluttering and I could not breath in the heat.  All these were side affects my Specialist denied, I finally got medical attention when my PCP saw that I could not raise myself off the table with wanting to throw up.  There are 3 degrees of side affects...I had all of them in one extreme or another, I also have Primary Biliary Cirrhosis.  I was hospitalized for 4 days.  My thyroid was at toxic levels!  Surgery with complete thyroidectomy leaving the parathyroid. Eighteen months later I finally feel good-minus the anxiety and depression.  Read your pharmacy hand outs, check Web MD and if your specialist denies your side affect could be related to PTU...get another Doctor!  And if you can't take PTU, you can't take any of the anti thyroid drugs cause they all have about the same side affects.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I switched from Tapazole to PTU when I found out I was pregnant and the bitterness after the pill made me more sick than just being pregnant! I tried everything to get rid of the horrible aftertaste that would linger from 5 minutes to 1 hour after taking the pill (4 times a day! Ouch!).After many tries, I found that taking the pill with chocolate milk helped me out at the beginning, but chewing a strong mint gum helped me out even more.  As soon as, or before, the bitter taste started to rise in my throat, I would pop a piece of gum and it did a great job of masking and hiding the bitterness.  Sometimes it would take a second piece of gum about 30 minutes later.  The hardest thing for me was trying to space out 4 pills a day and remembering to do it! Especially when I dreaded it.

SO THE MEDICINE DOES HELP SOME.

column9: I have been taking PTU for a year now and it seems to control very well.  I too get a bitter taste after taking, however, unlike some of you, my appetite seems to have increased!  Any suggestions?

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: PTU took about 4 weeks or more for me to show results in the bloodwork, but many of my symptoms got better more quickly than that (feeling extremely hot, itchy/allergy feeling on my skin, high metabolism).The taste is bad but hasn't made me sick.  My dosage started at 1.5 pills twice a day, and is now 1 pill twice a day.  The taste is not so prevalent now that I don't have to cut the pills.  This taste can last for hours in your mouth...I have noticed this kind of twinge-y reaction in my muscles, like I will reach for something not heavy (like a book) and feel like I just strained a muscle.

column2: andy, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I have been diagnosed with Graves Disease and my treatment is to tke PTU twice a day. At first it was a dificult transition. With a bitter taste and it would make me feel sick to my stomache. The nausea would make me lose my appetite and I would feel overwhelmingly tired. I'v been taking it for a year now and my levels have improved and my Doc has tapered down my dose to once a day. I just hope that I can go into remision soon.

column2: Dee, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I have been on 2 a day for a year.  My last blood work showed my white blood cells were 2.7, below normal, I find bruises and my gums bleed when brushing my teeth, my leg muscles are weakening, at some points I forget things..all this has been since I started the Propylthiouracil.

column2: boogs girl, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: i started take ptu about 3 months ago and i still get sick after i take....the taste of the pill i think is what causes me to..ive tryed with food and without. i also know that i am more tired now like i can sleep for days.i also take other meds like inderal for my graves desease..i am 32yrs old and i feel trapped by all of these meds i take 12 pills a day..cant they come up with one magic pill a day so people can feel normal as possible????they have bithcontrol in a shot ...i'll go every three months for that shot if they can put this pill in shot form..

column2: Wornout, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I was previously taking methimazole for Graves disease, but due to pregnancy had to start taking PTU. Im not at all happy with it. The taste is unbearable,not to mention the diarrhea, extreme weakness and tiredness, and the headaches. I also have stomache cramps and loss of appetite, which needless to say is not good during pregnancy. Would recommend taking care of thyroid, if possible, before pregnancy. If anything just to avoid this medication.

column2: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
liz, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I was suffering from anxiety and shakiness weight loss and fatigue.  After taking the medication for about 2 weeks I noticed a difference in these symptoms the decreased noticeably.  The only thing I dont like is taking a pill 2 or more times a day.

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I have been taking this medication for two weeks now and I have not really seen any change in my condition.  My doc told me it would take a while to notice the change so I am trying to be patient.  However, I seem to be developing a bad rash all over my calves and shins and am having some seriously bad joint pain in my knees and hips.  I am working on deciding for thyriod surgery or iodine treatment.  I will do one or the other since I have no children yet and want my body to be safe for when I do get pregnant.  Oh, and my suggestion for the taste is, if you can handle it, take the pills with milk.  I put a big drink of milk in my mouth first, then drop the pill in and swallow all.  I then basically chug a whole glass of milk.  It seems to help a little and is good for the ole bones too! Good luck everyone! :)

column2: Mom-on-Meds, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I've read all the reviews posted and for me, I discovered that the fatigue, weakness and inability to sleep was not the medication but my condition.  It does take a while to take effect.  I started out taking in 2x's per day but my blood tests weren't evening out which my endo. recommended I take it 3x's per day.  My hair and nails started to grow back strong which let me know it was working.  I also took the propranolol to help with my heart rate.  My only problem was I was breast feeding my child and the doctor recommended I stop.  He was not very sympathic to the fact I had a child and thought I could just cut my baby off cold turkey.  I would find myself not taking it when I was around her but I'd take the meds at work.  I also noticed when I didn't take it for say a week and tried to start it again, I'd have a reaction with my skin.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I had the radioactive iodine treatment after being diagnosed with hyperthyroidism. After the iodine treatment, my hyperthyroidism was still above average. Around two months after the iodine treatment I became pregnant, and had to continue treatment with PTU. I was afraid of how PTU would affect my child. Because I still had grave's disease my child was born with neonatal hyperthyroidism. I would suggest complete treatment of hyperthyroidism before plans to conceive especially if you do not want your child to go through as much treatment as you've experienced. Since giving birth recently I have tried researching Neonatal Hyperthyroidism, unfortunately there isn't enough information available about the condition. In response to the bitter taste of the medication, I suggest taking it with Cranberry juice.

column2: troll baby, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: this medicine has caused my levels to be somewhat, what they should be. i havnt had to have radiation and wont because of the harm to my kids

column2: DAWN,  Female  (Patient)
column9: IM SCARED TO TAKE MED BECAUSE I AM PREGNANT.WHAT RISK FACTORS DOES IT CAUSE FOR MY UNBORN CHILD

column2: LookingForAnswers, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have taken this medicing for a total of 3 months.  It has proven to lower my levels back down into the normal range, however I have had serious nausea with this medicine.  I have actually been extremely sick to my stomach and this medication, which I only take one time a day.  Another con to this medicine is that I cannot sleep more than two hours a night.  Nor, do I have an appitite.  As opposed to having the surgery, I am trying to lower my dosage with the pill by taking only half.  Because my levels were so good after four weeks of the medication, I can handle the 'side effects' well enough to continue the pill.

column2: jml1, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: 3+months later still being told that blood show that pills still not working

column2: christy, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I have been on PTU since 2001. The med is only bitter to me after i take it. Its horrible. I would rather take PTU than have surgery. I am experiencing the numbness and stomach pains as said in other reviews. I have an appt. with Doc. to discuss this. If you have these symptoms you should also discuss with your Doc.

column2: dn, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Just started taking (2 weeks) dont have any symptonms, I have bitter taste in my mouth!

column2: young and unhealthy, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have been taking this medication for about a month now and it has made me very week and tired often. My heart has an irregular rhythm that causes my head to hurt.I am hoping that the effects will change soon because so far this has been the only option for treatment given to me by my healtcare physician.

column2: htopcat12@aol.com, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Medication is easy to take but the side effects have been difficult to deal with. My G.p prescribed propranolol 80mg mr capules t allieviate some of the unplesant shaking and anxiety. These worked well for me and I continued to take at same time as antithyroid medication roughly every eight hours, I stopped shaking and was able to go out without feeling too anxious, now another medical person requests that all three capules are taken in one go at night, I don't understand why.

column2: vawendyann, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: Began taking this drug at age 12 until age 18 when after radioactive iodine I had a sub-total thyroidectomy.  While on this drug I experienced stomach pain.  Years later, I began to experience muscle and joint pain, tingling, and weakness first in my legs then arms.  Also numbness on the right side of my face. I gradually became numb in most of my left foot and areas of my right foot and legs.  After 13 years of medical tests and specialists, my doctor says it is Peripheral Neuropathy but has not found a definite cause.  I am beginning to suspect the 6 years of being on Propylthiouracil might be the cause.  Any help researching this would be welcome.

column2: june, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I recently had my thyroid out due to nodules on my thyroid discovered by my gyn not my endo dr. I was on PTU for 9 yrs. My surgeon said my thyroid hardened due to autoimmune symtoms relating to taking PTU. Such as Lupus side effect. Now I am being treated for hypoparathyroidism (I take 4500mg of calcium a day @ the clock) and still recovering from surgery.  My thyroid was imbedded in neck muscles making it difficult in swallowing, talking, and turning my head. I wish now that I knew more about PTU and other options.  My surgeon also told me that PTU is a form of chemotherpy...shocking.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: At first effective at treating my hyperthyroidism during pregnancy.  Have since had my child and after a short break without it, am back on the medication.  I've developed a serious rash, joint pain, headache and fever that may be attributed to the medication.  Please talk to your doctor immediately if you notice any unusual changes in your body.  I am now forced to consider radioactive iodine treatment earlier than expected.

column9: Worked very well to control my thyroid and was safe enough to use during pregnancy.  If it's not working for you, your dose may be too low - talk to your endocrinologist!
